text: Geodes like this one form when silica dissolved in groundwater precipitates to form quartz crystals that grow within cavities in rocks .

Because they are located in arid regions with high evaporation rates , these water bodies regularly precipitate the minerals halite , sylvite , and gypsum , as well as other soluble salts , called evaporite deposits .
Once saturation is reached , the ions begin to bond , forming crystalline solids ( called salts ) that precipitate from ( settle out of ) the solution .
Minerals can also precipitate from slowly moving groundwater filling in fractures and voids in rocks and sediments .
One interesting example , called a geode , is a somewhat spherically shaped object with inwardprojecting crystals that were gradually deposited by groundwater .
The Great Salt Lake in Utah and Bolivia ’s great salt flat , Salar de Uyuni , provide good examples of this process at work .
Perhaps the most familiar way in which minerals grow is from an aqueous ( water ) solution containing dissolved material matter ( ions ) .
Geodes sometimes contain spectacular crystals of quartz , calcite , or other less common minerals .
As long as the solution is not saturated , the motion of the dissolved ions keeps them from joining together .
Two factors — a drop in temperature and water lost through evaporation — cause the solution to become closer to reaching saturation .
Worldwide , extensive evaporite deposits , some exceeding hundreds of meters in thickness , provide evidence of ancient seas that have long since evaporated ( see page 100 ) .
This process is discussed in greater detail in Chapter 4 .
In 1970 , South Africa dominated global gold production — accounting for 79 % of production throughout the world .
Gold has been treasured since long before recorded history for its beauty .
